reviewText:
Early Access Review

Drive Any Track is a point to point racer that generates tracks based of your own music collection. While it sits in the same genre as games like Audiosurf, adding the cars with amazing drift handling really allows DAT to hold it's own. Not just a decent music generated game but one of the better arcade racers I've played in some time. Highly addictive and upon first play I was mesmerized by my screen for hours. The King is dead, long live the King.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6qbVac0yjtw
Gameplay is simple, select a song, choose your car and burn rubber. Tracks are all given a star rating which dictate their difficulty and harder levels generally contained more obstacles and tighter turns.  Provided the song includes an id3 tag your score also gets uploaded to both local and global leaderboards. Tried a wide range of genres from classical through to chiptune and overall music generation was not only quick but produced some wonderful results.  Faster music had more jumps and loops while slower music seemed much more drift based.

While there is still plenty to add in future (real-time lighting, skyboxes etc), Graphically speaking it already looks quite tron-like and beautiful. Currently in-game options were slim to none but given the minimalistic nature of the game I would hazard a guess it should run very well on a wide range of systems. Didn't skip a beat scaling up to 4k+ on a single 970. Something that did seem to be missing was a bunch of default music tracks which was a little unfortunate as I'm sure it would help with the competitive side of the game.

Most of the features I would like to see included in future are already planned. Such as further control of stunts, improved tracking of stats and additional game modes, cars and environments. With that said DAT contains 12 standard cars (+2 secret), decent selection of liveries and enough change of environment and colour schemes that it stays fresh. The games few downsides like sometimes being stuck on your roof following a dodgy jump, or hurtling round a corner into a badly placed wall are easily outweighed by all the upsides.

Overall if you're a fan of music based games or arcade racers such as Ridge Racer, RUSH, Burnout, Daytona or Outrun. DAT is well worth your weekly allowance and has got my stamp of approval. Cheers folks, now back to racing. :]

reviewText:
I was hesitating on this one since a lot of rhythm type games that generate tracks from user audio files feel kinda bland or else they have the problem of only being fun if you are using EDM tracks with heavy, distinctive beats. I was watching some trailers as well and was hesitating because I couldn't really discern what the game was doing with the tracks that would make them truly feel like you were playing the song.

After spending just a short amount of time with it, it's winning me over very fast. It's called Riff Racer, which suggests guitar riffs, which suggests it should be fun with rock music, whereas a lot of music/rhythm games that procedurally generate tracks are not super good with rock tracks. I was super impressed to discover that playing rock tracks in this game feels very satisfying and the game can specifically detect if you are a playing a rock/metal track.

As I was playing these rock songs, which don't have the heavy, distinctive beats that EDM tracks have, I kinda started to warm up to the things the game was doing to make you feel like you were playing the song. It was less about individual beats and more about the energy of the song. Placing a speed boost right when the chorus takes off. Dropping a huge ramp right when the song tears into a guitar solo. Shifting the lighting and colors to fiery hot as the song picks up speed and volume.

Where Riff Racer lacks at emphasizing the individual beats of a song, it seems to excel at getting the visceral energy of a song just right. Of course I'd advise you to mostly pick out a songs that suit a game about hitting ramps in a fast car.

The game has great controller support and the controls are fantastic. The driving feels almost as good as games like Mario Kart or Sonic All-Star Racing Transformed. The drifting takes a bit of getting used to, but its starts to make more sense the more you practice it.

It's an arcade racer, so it's all about racking up points. Unlike other rhythm games, which focus on hitting the good objects and dodging the bad objects, Riff Racer does something slightly different. Hitting the good objects instead builds up a boost meter that you can use to trigger a manual boost (in addition to free boosts lying on the track). In order to get the most points, you need to go as fast as possible for as long as possible, hit collectibles, hit ramps (especially at an angle so that you can spiral jump for extra points), and execute long drifts around sharp corners. The faster and fancier you drive without falling off the track, flipping the car, or crashing into things, the more points you'll rack up. It's not just about hitting those beats (although it's that too); it's also about kicking butts.

And of course there are global leaderboards, friend leaderboards, personal best, etc. The game comes with a bunch of songs bundled in, and you can use your own. You also gain points for racing tracks, and those points let you unlock new cars and paint jobs. The new cars and paint jobs are merely cosmetic, but it gives you something to work toward if you need that kind of motivation.

The only downside to the game is that once you put 4 or 5 hours into it, race all of your favorite rock tracks, then you've pretty much seen the whole tour. You can still go back and score attack, but you're basically racing time trial on tracks that---while very fun---are largely similar, so it starts to get a little samey after a while.

Rating the game on the scale below, I give it a hearty 6:

7) A classic, essential, and/or must-buy game that is worth full price.
6) A good game that is worth the full price.
5) A pretty good game worth checking out--especially if discounted.4) A fairly good game, but I'd recommend buying it discounted.
3) Not great, but a few redeeming qualities. Only buy if heavily discounted.
2) Only worth checking out if you are dangerously curious.
1) Avoid at all costs.

Early Access Review

So far I'm pretty addicted to this game. My love for music might be an influence. Being able to race to the music on your own PC is really fun and games that do this always grab my attention. DAT is infact a great Early Access title and I've already begun racking up hours played. Even though its an EA title, it has plenty of content to enjoy right now. Unlock cars by leveling up or collecting tokens and buying them. You can also change the paint scheme on any of them with a few tokens as well. The gameplay's difficulty depends on the song you play. If you play something really slow and soft, you're gonna have an easy track but switch it over to something more upbeat and fast and you'll find a real challenge. On the track you'll find 2 types of pickups. The boxy one fills up your boost and the coin looking ones are for spending in the garage on cars and paintjobs. The purpose of the game is to stay up with the first line of synchonization. I believe there are 4 total and if you fall behind, you will be resynced. If you have friends that own the game you can race against their ghosts if you want and try to get better times on the songs they have played but I'm pretty sure you have to own the song yourself. The store lists the game with multiplayer as well. Unfortunately I have yet to get to try this since I'm playing before release, I will update this review with info on multiplayer once I get to try it.
There are also leaderboards but the song you play must have an ID3 tag on it if you wish for the game to keep your score and place it on the leaderboards. (An ID3 tag is a little scrap of data added to the beginning or end of the MP3 file which stores information about the audio recording including the title, artist, album, copyright date, and musical genre.) I'm assuming this is how they keep track of the leaderboard scores. If you have music without a tag you can always get something like MP3Info, a great utility that adds ID3 tags and customizing to files.
All in all I would say this game has great potential and recommend it to anyone who loves driving games and music.

Early Access Review

The concept of this game is pretty fun. It's rare to see a music game where you're quite literally competing against the music. This game's got a lot of potential, and I'm already enjoying it more than games like Audiosurf. However, since it's Early Access (and it's only been out for one day) it's pretty rough around the edges. Sometimes the game will generate a huge jump right before a sharp turn, or create a barrier around a corner that you could never hope to see in time. Things like these can ruin your score, and it's the game's fault rather than your lack of skill. I've also clipped straight through the track more than once, and sometimes when you come out of a drift your car has a tendency to overcorrect itself and careen into a wall (tough cookies if this happens right before an ill-timed jump). I know it's an early access game, and I know there's no such thing as a bug free game, but these problems are the things they really need to iron out first.

When the game works, I can't stress how much fun it is. It's certainly in a playable state, and it can only get better from here. I say go ahead and pick it up now before the price increases over time as the game gets fleshed out.

I'm a huge ♥♥♥♥ing sucker for music generated games meaning games that make levels based on the mp3 files you choose from your computer.
I played Audiosurf, Audiosurf 2, Beat Hazard, Symphony and Crypt of the Necrodancer. Drive Any Track is definitely one of the best music generated games in my opinion.

If you played Audiosurf -- I'm guessing most people who look at this page have played that -- just imagine that but you control your vehicle like a car of a racing game (including drifting, jumping, stunting, crashing) and instead of collecting right colored blocks this is just about driving perfectly through the course. Must be the music I like, since even the slow music sometimes throws me off the track with ramp after ramp after ramp.  That being said ...

This is a great game.  It's quite enjoyable to run the tracks trying to get a decent score while listening to music you enjoy.

Most of my music is two stars, with a few three stars, and I've had a few pop up as four stars.  I've yet to see a five star song from my music ...  Maybe I should be careful what I ask for, as four star songs are pretty wild!

The way you get points is by doing stunts.  You keep ahead of the first bar for maximum points.  Just driving doesn't get you anything, although you can use periods where you need to just drive to collect coins (for buying different cars and skins) and boost pack thingies (that you can use to activate your own boost whenever you want ... provided you've collected enough of them).

You always take about the same amount of time to make it through the track, so to get points you do stunts.  You run over ramps, getting as much air time as possible.  To get more points, you hit the ramps so the car spins ... but this comes with a number of issues that really justifies the extra score.  For instance, if you hit the ramp wrong, it's possible to land on your roof, or be flung from the map altogether!  So be very very very careful jumping, especially if you plan on doing the high scoring spins!

You also get points by drifting.  I suppose this can be abused, but whenever I've used drifting unnecessarily, I've always bounced off the walls.  Great way to fall behind, thus losing points!

When you use the boost, it helps you get caught up, or you can use it just before a series of jumps to get ahead of the bar, increasing your point yield.  I'm the sort who tries to get more bang for my buck, so I always try to optimize when I use it.  But I rarely play the same track twice in a row, so it's always something of a gamble for me.

If you play the same track over a few times to get the highest score you can, you won't have to wait for it to rebuild the track. My Honest Review: Drive Any Track - 15/07/08
IntroI've always been fascinated by games that take audio/music and create unique tracks based on the highs and lows of songs. Audiosurf and its sequel have been long-time favorites for me. However, there was always something missing. There isn't a large amount of control you can give as you glide across a track to your favorite music.

That's where Drive Any Track comes in. It improves upon that concept by giving you much more control over what you do on that track. You see that sharp turn over there? Yeeeeaaaaah... you can friggin' drift around that like a pro racer. What about that jump? Evil Knievel that as you sing along to the song. You have more control over how you literally drive the song.

Gameplay
The gameplay is a mixture of avoiding obstacles, collecting boxes for points/boost, collecting tokens for in-game customization, jumping off ramps (and landing them) all while staying in sync with the song you are playing. If you hit a barricade? You're going to lose some speed and possibly lose sync. Fail a jump? You might as well restart if you want that 100% bonus.

As you finish songs to completion, you are given a place on the leaderboard for that song. If you were the first one to play that song, you are credited with being the track creator. Additionally, you are given XP for completing the song, which levels you up (which unlocks cars). The tokens you gathered throughout the songs can be used to buy paint-jobs for the cars you own.

The game is essentially simple, which is to be expected of Early Access. Hopefully the developer adds some more game modes and spices up track generation.

Graphics/Sounds/Controls The game has simple graphics that allow the game to be played on a majority of low-end computers. The game is more focused on using simple, abstract and vibrant colors and lights to give the game more of an arcade-y feel that allows the game to portray different genres. I have not run into any performance issues as of yet.

Sounds are entirely based on the quality of the audio file you are using. I recommend using the highest quality file to ensure the best listening pleasure.

I have not used anything other than a keyboard for this game, so my experience in controllers or gamepads is non-existent. I can say that the games controls are simple and easy to learn. Playing on the keyboard is very useable as well. No need for controllers.

Replayability The game's replayability is entirely dependant on the size of your music library. However, there are some problems where some songs will be given the wrong difficulty. Also, while every song has a unique track, it may get monotonous. The lack of different modes leave things to be desired.

Overall The game is really good, it has massive potential. We just need some more modes to spice things up and increase replayability.

Update 4/4/16 Reflecting on some of the changes made to the game I still really enjoy it, the option for manual acceleration si more than welcome and gives you a greater feel of control, thumbs up there.

Also I see tweaks made which make the tracks and obstacles seem much more fitting with the music track.

https://youtu.be/BkqM6U-hHIc

As a music based game,this is a breathe of fresh air, I do like Audio surf a lot, but where as it can become total chaos on that game, DAT is a less stress inducing way of enjoying a game being generated by your own music. That`s not to say it wont set you a challenge though, because it will depending on the music you use.

Something that does get me a bit though is that it does not really seem in synch with your music, yes it does generate unique tracks, but there does not seem to be much to indicate the track your racing is like racing your music. For example, while you maybe in synch with the track marker, pickups that you collect don`t seem to have a rythmic pattern following the music your racing to, I really think this should be looked at and tweaked. They really should be more inline with the beat, or lead sound of the music, and maybe more of them.

I do agree about some walls too, they can at times appear in obscure places, like right on a bend, or hill top so you don`t get chance to react, so again needs tweaking.

I really do enjoy when it gets to the part of the track with loads of drifting, and in most cases it feels right, it feels that it belongs in that certain part of your music.

On a final niggle, sometimes track generation difficulty can be confusing, I have tried a drum n bass track and it was given an easy difficulty rating, and was really easy to drive, but then I tried a soft rock track and it cranked up to 4 star difficulty. Rather baffling.

I do recommend this game though, I have lost hours on it, and will more as well, and I hope that over time the engine will be fine tuned to iron out some of these niggles, along with even more excitement and variety of scenes.

If you like Audiosurf, you will love this game. It was a frustrating start but after I practiced with the controls a bit, I do a bit better now. There are some great things and some not so great things so I will try to list them all.

Great things:
-Plenty of cars and paints for the cars.
-Visually stunning.
-Simple yet challenging.
-Track variation is pretty good, although I have found a few songs where most of the song is just drifting back and forth which is quite boring. For the most part though, the tracks are pretty good.
-Shiny!


Not so great things:
-If you have a downloaded song through YouTube or some other source, there is no leader board for that song.
-Sometimes downloaded songs will play as a different songs
-Barricades are placed in bad spots from time to time. Sometimes they are impossible to avoid unless you have the track memorized.
-Visuals can become distracting if your eyes are sensitive to bright colors, flashes, and other such effects.
-Controls are wonky. They just do not feel consistent. Sometimes they respond slow. Sometimes they are too twitchy (Example: pulling out of a drift will slam you into a wall)
-Crate and token hitboxes are not consistent either. Sometimes you can drive right next to them and pick them up, other times they won't get picked up.
-Lack of control customization and not being able to use mouse/gamepad. You cannot change controls. The controls consist of <- -> [spacebar] and CTRL. There was little tutorial too. I was unsure that I could drift until about my 20th race and then i got a tip saying CTRL was to drift.


Overall, considering this is Early access, It is in pretty good shape. There are a few minor things that need to be changed/tweaked/added. But overall, it was worth the money. I would suggest this game to any music lover.

A wonderful game that can stand up to other music based games very well, as this game has more haptic gameplay elements than the others. Immediately the comparison is made to audiosurf, and I personally prefer this, as your ability to control the direction and speed of the vehicle as well as being able to be slowed down or drift creates a great feeling of weight and control, thus making it feel more immersive in comparison.
Driving using your own music is something people have wanted in many driving and open world games, and this helps fit that desire. Most general music file formats seem to be supported, and the leaderboard support complete with ghosts to race against makes this game feel well thought out.
The only issue I can state at time of release is that when racing against ghosts, it's not always clear how they gain points, which can be irritating as improving your skills and tactics is difficult when you have no idea how you lost.
Outside of that minor complaint, I can highly recommend this game.
It runs very well and looks great, but to note it is stylized and from an indie studio, I am more basing the intended graphics compared to what was seen, and there doesnt appear to be many errors or poor quality visuals.
This is a must buy if you are a fan of custom music based games.

reviewText:
I really liked this game, it's fun and simple, there are no if's or but's about it. The controls are very simple, basic driving movement keys [Though default bound to arrows and not wsad] with the drift function being controlled from spacebar (Saints Row 3 anyone?) and a boost button for when you fill your boost meter, which is cleverly displayed on the car and not a HUD.

The cars themselves are many once you can afford them [W/ In-game coins found within songs] and the designs are radical but remnescent, fitting into the game world perfectly while maintaining styles that many of us should be able to recognize features of.

The tracks [Road/Highway] are very colorful, as anyone here who has played audiosurf will easily relate to, fitting the music in a good way, with little dancing pixels colorized and moving to the beat of the music. There are stright-ways, loops, jumps, and drift streches, all of which are pretty fun to drive on, all except the drift areas containing barricades you want to advoid. My biggest issue was jumping off the side of the track and hitting barracades while going for coins, but it was all fun, the gameplay isn't overly challenging and the cars are manuverable in air, making mistakes like that semi recoverable. This is  -not- Dark Souls DJ'ing on wheels, this is a fun game ment for everyone.

Coins end up being used for buying new cars and customization options for the cars you do own. You start off with one car that has one unlocked customization, a sporty design in a pretty blue. The songs seem to vary in coins amoung them, I had one song go as low as 90 coins and another up to 250. This does help keep the game a little more appealing since you end up setting goals for getting the cars and paints, though I am only left to wonder that if 250 coins per song is good, then cars and paints costing 20k+ would take quike awhile to get. You do level up as you gain experience points from each song and I can only assume higher levels gives higher coin multiplyers, but that is just my assumption and in no way should I ever be quoted on it.

I don't have any gripes, as much as I tried to find one. While I was playing with the truck I did see my truck reflecting off the truck, which... makes no sence... and I once had a spotlight-beam cross the road for a second, but the map is littered with spotlights, as well as many other eye glittering detail. I have not been able to have this issue reoccure since, even on the same song it appeared on. The only thing that I would like to see is a super drift mode, or maybe a split game from this using the same physics, as the drift portions are very fun and arcade-like. I suppose one can compain about car customization being basic, but in this game there is so many colors and lights that you really only get to fully appreciate your car paint job when not driving.

I'm a fan of arcade racing games and music games, audiosurf was the actual reason I made a steam account in the first place, and I now own sevral custom-music based games. With a game like this, I was only naturaly drawn to it once I saw it in the featured store page, and I haft to say, this game is worth it. Very worth it. It is fun, simple, and effective at staying just that. If you like music-based games, specialy ones that use your music, I would highly recommend this, even if you're not a driving-game fan. This game has its heart in the music, and that is something I can appreciate.

If you like music runner games, as well as racing games, well then hot damn do I have a game for you!

The game seems to be a blend of the arcade-y, drifting-based handling of Ridge Racer, and the intense color pallette/vibing feel of Audiosurf, from what I can tell after about 2 hours of play.

On the positive side of the game, it so far has accurately synced up with any song i've thrown at it's engine; the music-generated maps change color and theme depending on the genre of music/intensity of the current moment in the song, with the choices in theme being appropriate thus far; there are many options in the way of what your car looks like, with unlockable rides that you can further customize after purchasing, all using in-game coins earned through playing the game. Kinda sad that has to be a positive side of a game nowadays, huh? Anyways, the actual racing" itself is done against the pace of the song by way of pace bars you need to try to keep up with to stay synced with the song; the drifting and speed of the game feel incredibly satisfying

This is one of those game that you lose track of time in. Going through my  library of music on my hard drive to find the best driving song is a blast, and before you know it you sunk over an hour into it. That said, the algorithm in place to make tracks out of your music does have its issues. Sometimes on the harder difficulties, I find unavoidable barriers, jumps impossible to make without boost, and oddly placed boost pickups. Since this game is in Early Access, I know that these issues will probably get ironed out. That being said, The game has lots of different futuristic looking cars to drive with different visual liveries for each. The drift mechanic is fun and feels satisfying to get a big drift combo, but it would be nice to be able to chain your drift combo through turns without losing your streak.

Pros:
- Lots of Cars
- Endless amount of levels
- Pick up and play
- Addicting

Cons:
- Algorithm needs tweaking
- Addicting

All in all, this game is fun and I highly recommend it!
